stories.headline: US Supreme Court Strikes Down Trump's Global Tariffs
stories.body: The US Supreme Court has ruled that President Trump's sweeping global tariffs are illegal, upending a central plank of his economic agenda. The landmark decision represents a major check on executive power over trade policy.

stories.headline: Prince Andrew Arrested in Epstein Investigation
stories.body: Prince Andrew has been arrested and released under investigation, with police searches at Royal Lodge expected to continue until Monday. The arrest has sent shockwaves through the British monarchy and reignited calls for accountability in the Epstein case on both sides of the Atlantic.

stories.headline: Ukraine-Russia Peace Talks Stall as US Military Builds Up Near Iran
stories.body: Ukraine's patience with the US-brokered peace push is wearing thin as Russia skirts diplomatic pressure, while simultaneously a rapid US military build-up near Iran -- including an aircraft carrier spotted off Gibraltar -- raises the spectre of a second conflict in the Middle East.

stories.headline: Peru's President Ousted in Express Impeachment
stories.body: Peru's president has been removed from office after just four months in what has been described as an "express impeachment," with a leftist lawmaker who previously defended child marriage elected as interim president.

stories.headline: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling Upends Trump's Economic Agenda
stories.body: In the most significant judicial rebuke of the Trump administration to date, the Supreme Court struck down the president's sweeping global tariffs, throwing his trade policy into disarray. Republicans have urged Trump to refocus on domestic priorities after what observers called a "head-spinning day" of policy setbacks.

stories.headline: California Avalanche Kills Eight Backcountry Skiers
stories.body: Recovery crews are working to retrieve the bodies of eight backcountry skiers killed in a devastating avalanche in the Sierra Nevada, with one person still missing. The victims included a group of six mothers who had bonded over outdoor adventures. Investigations are now examining whether anyone was at fault.

stories.headline: Federal Judge Blasts Trump Administration Over Immigration Enforcement
stories.body: A federal judge has accused the Trump administration of conducting a campaign of "terror" against immigrants in a scathing ruling, as separate cases emerge of an ICE arrest where a man suffered severe head injuries and a cherished teacher killed in a crash involving a driver being pursued by immigration agents.

stories.headline: Epstein Fallout Widens Across US Institutions
stories.body: The release of Epstein files continues to generate fallout, with Bard College opening a review of its president's ties to the financier, billionaire Les Wexner claiming he was "conned," and a once-prominent American statesman facing new scrutiny.

stories.headline: Police Sexual Assault Scandal Engulfs Interior Ministry
stories.body: Spain's Interior Ministry is in crisis after a female police officer accused the former head of operations (DAO) of sexual assault, with new evidence including a key audio recording presented to the court. The officer also accused a police union leader of posting her details on a prostitution website. The ministry has placed her under protection and is reportedly considering appointing a woman as the new DAO to address the crisis.

stories.headline: BBVA and Former President Prosecuted in Villarejo Case
stories.body: The Audiencia Nacional will try banking giant BBVA and its former president Francisco Gonzalez for their role in hiring disgraced former police commissioner Jose Villarejo for corporate espionage.

stories.headline: Spain Asks EU to Lift Sanctions on Venezuela's Delcy Rodriguez
stories.body: The Spanish government has moved quickly to ask the European Union to lift sanctions on Venezuelan vice president Delcy Rodriguez, hours after Venezuela approved an amnesty law. The request has drawn criticism from opposition parties.

stories.headline: Vox Internal Rebellion as Ortega Smith Defies Party Leadership
stories.body: Ortega Smith has mounted the biggest internal rebellion against Vox leader Abascal, clinging to his role as party spokesperson in the Madrid city council despite orders to step aside. Meanwhile, Vox has launched a campaign to ban halal menus in school canteens.

stories.headline: Sagrada Familia Reaches Its Highest Point
stories.body: The Sagrada Familia has completed the summit of the Tower of Jesus at 172.5 metres, placing the three-dimensional cross that now crowns Antoni Gaudi's masterpiece 144 years after the first stone was laid. The milestone completes all six central towers of the basilica.

stories.headline: Rodalies Chaos Continues a Month After Gelida Accident
stories.body: One month after the train accident at Gelida, Catalunya's commuter rail network Rodalies is still operating with severe disruptions, with 200 track sections under speed restrictions next week -- half caused by the October storm. The upcoming closure of the Garraf tunnels presents yet another mobility challenge south of Barcelona.

stories.headline: Catalunya Withdraws 247 Publicly Funded Places from Gender-Segregated Schools
stories.body: The Catalan government has announced the removal of 247 publicly funded school places from institutions that segregate students by sex, as part of broader changes to the concerted education system. Private schools warn the renewals will cost them 165 groups over six years.

stories.headline: Illa Pledges Full Commitment on Tax Collection to Secure ERC Budget Support
stories.body: President Illa has assured ERC that his commitment to Catalan management of income tax (IRPF) collection is "total," in a bid to unblock the regional budget negotiations with the pro-independence party.

stories.headline: L'Hospitalet Crime Rises 10% as Mayor Announces Security Plan
stories.body: L'Hospitalet de Llobregat has recorded a 10% increase in crime, prompting Mayor Nuria Parlon to announce a "shock plan" to tackle insecurity in Barcelona's neighbouring city. Meanwhile, residents gave the new administration of David Quiros a barely passing grade in its first public assessment.
